title: King Charles III Strips Prince Andrew of Titles, Evicts from Royal Lodge

The rare move comes after mounting pressure to act over Andrew's relationship with sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.
The move by King Charles follows revelations about Andrew's relationship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein.

summary: King Charles III has removed Prince Andrew's royal titles and evicted him from his Royal Lodge residence, requiring him to move into private accommodation. This decision, described by Buckingham Palace in stark terms, follows scrutiny over Andrew's association with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. The action represents a significant and rare rebuke within the royal family, highlighting the ongoing impact of the scandal on Andrew's position.

title: Trump Admin Sets Refugee Cap at Record Low, Prioritizes Afrikaners
snippets: The lowest cap on refugees since the program was established in 1980 comes as the U.S. prioritizes resettling Afrikaners from South Africa.
The president sets the limit at 7,500 for the coming year, a dramatic cut from 125,000.
Live updates: Trump administration limits refugee admissions to mostly white South Africans AP News
Trump sets 7,500 annual limit for refugees entering US. It’ll be mostly white South Africans AP News
President says US will prioritise white South Africans in move decried by refugee advocates as blatantly political.
The US will cut the number of refugees allowed into the country to 7,500 next year, the White House has said, adding most would be Afrikaners from South Africa.

Low number represents a dramatic drop after US previously allowed in hundreds of thousands of people fleeing war and persecution The Trump administration is going to restrict the number of refugees it admits into the United States next year to the token level of just 7,500 – and those spots will mos
Trump sets refugee ceiling at record-low 7,500 with focus on white South Africans Reuters
titles: Trump administration sets lowest-ever cap on refugee admissions to U.S.

summary: The Trump administration has set the refugee admission limit to a record low of 7,500 for the upcoming year, marking the lowest cap since the program's inception in 1980. This decision represents a significant reduction from the previous limit of 125,000. The administration has announced a prioritization for resettling Afrikaners from South Africa, a move that has been criticized by refugee advocates as politically motivated. This policy shift focuses on admitting mostly white South Africans, diverging from the program's historical emphasis on assisting individuals fleeing war and persecution

title: Trump Orders Resumption of US Nuclear Testing After 30-Year Pause
snippets: The U.S. has not conducted a nuclear test in over 30 years. Experts say doing one now could make America less safe.
Experts say Trump's direction for the U.S. to resume nuclear testing is dangerous to populations and would open a door for adversaries to sharpen their weapons.
ABC News senior Pentagon reporter Luis Martinez on President Donald Trump ordering the Pentagon to resume nuclear testing on an "equal basis" to other countries' testing programs.

US president makes threat after Russian nuclear-powered weapons tests and shortly before meeting with Chinese leader Donald Trump has instructed the Pentagon to immediately start matching other nuclear powers in their testing of nuclear weapons, specifically citing Russia and China. In a post to Tru
Though the country’s nuclear arsenal has undergone no explosive testing for decades, federal experts say it can reliably obliterate targets halfway around the globe.

U.S. President Donald Trump, ahead of his meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping on Thursday, said he has instructed the Department of Defence to immediately resume testing nuclear weapons on an "equal basis" with other nuclear powers.
Trump Orders Nuclear Weapons Trials After Russia Tests Bloomberg.com
Nuclear testing: Why did it stop, why test and who has nuclear weapons? Reuters
Trump tells Pentagon to resume testing US nuclear weapons Reuters
Trump appears to suggest the US will resume testing nuclear weapons for first time in 30 years AP News
The president said he wanted testing to occur “on an equal basis” with Russia and China. The Kremlin condemned the move, and there was no indication of when tests might take place.
President Trump's Truth Social announcement that the US will pursue new nuclear weapons testing raises more questions than it answers.

summary: President Donald Trump has ordered the Pentagon to resume nuclear weapons testing, aiming to match the testing activities of other nuclear powers such as Russia and China. This directive comes after a hiatus of over 30 years without nuclear testing by the U.S. Experts warn that resuming tests could endanger global safety and lead to an arms race. The decision was announced ahead of Trump's meeting with Chinese President Xi Jinping and has sparked criticism from various quarters, including the Kremlin. There is no specified timeline for when the testing might begin.
